_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Lumen Midstream Partnership, LLC (Lumen) has developed this Risk Management Plan (RMP) in order to implement 40 CFR Part 68, the federal requirements regulating Risk Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals for the Kingman Gas Plant (Facility), located in Kingman County, Cheney, Kansas.  The legal description for the Facility is Section 33, Township 27 South, Range 9 West. The Kingman Gas Plant has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention (e.g., training of plant personnel, considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of the facility). The Facility's approach is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances as well as other substances. If a release does occur, the Facility's personnel will take steps to shut down the facility, safely evacuate, notify emergency responders and deny access to the facility area to the general public. 



This RMP will help prevent the occurrence of, or minimize the consequences of, catastrophic releases by stating policies and procedures for the management of process hazards in start-up, operation, inspection, maintenance, and other matters addressed in the federal requirements regulating risk management of highly hazardous chemicals.



This document reflects the conditions at the Kingman Gas Plant as they exist during the time of the RMP preparation. The offsite consequence analysis (OCA) has been developed using the current population determined by MARPLOT, 2010 U.S. Census Data estimations. The OCA determines the Facility's Risk Management Program facility status based on the criteria in 40 CFR Part 68, the federal requirements regulating risk management of highly hazardous chemicals.  Section 112(r) of the amended Clean Air Act (CAA), signed into law on November 15, 1990, mandates a federal focus on the prevention of chemical accidents.  The objective of Section 112(

r) is to prevent serious chemical accidents that have the potential to affect public health and the environment.  Under these requirements, industry has the obligation to prevent accidents, operate safely, and manage hazardous chemicals in a safe and responsible way. 



The risk management planning requirements of the CAA Section 112(r) complement and support the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act of 1986 (EPCRA).  EPCRA helps local communities prepare for and respond to chemical accidents.  It also requires communities to develop emergency response plans, based on information from industry concerning hazardous chemicals.  Under the CAA 112(r) requirements, stationary sources (facilities) must identify and assess their chemical hazards and carry out certain activities designed to reduce the likelihood and severity of accidental chemical releases.  



The OCA is a component of the CAA Section 112(r) and includes an evaluation of the regulated chemicals to be stored at the Facility and the simulation of a worst-case and an alternate case release of those chemicals.  The simulation is conducted to determine if the Facility will have off-site consequences affecting any surrounding public receptors.  



The OCA and RMP will help prevent the occurrence, or minimize the consequences of catastrophic releases by stating policies and procedures for the management of process hazards in start-up, operation, inspection, maintenance and the other matters addressed in the federal regulations for risk management of highly hazardous chemicals.



The Facility maintains a written emergency action plan, which is in place to protect workers, the public, and the environment. The program consists of evacuation procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The action plan includes intruction to provide proper first aid and medical treatment for exposure

s, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, and notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs. The plan includes instruction to deny access to the general public to the affected area. Employees will participate in post accident reviews as requested by the LEPC. In addition, the Facility has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific duties. The emergency action plan is updated when necessary.



This emergency action plant is coordinated with the Kingman County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), City of Cheney Fire Department and the Kingman County Sheriff's Department. These organizations are responsible (if necessary) for notifying the public, coordinating the community response (e.g., blocking off roads, evacuation), and providing onsite response (e.g., firefighting, medical treatment). The Facility conducts periodic emergency action table top drills and provides periodic refreshers to the local emergency response organizations on the hazards associated with the plant operations.
